awd_titl_txt: RUI: Arboreal Galois Groups and Nonarchimedean Dynamics
awd_abstract_narration:
This project concerns certain open questions in arithmetic dynamics, a field bridging number theory and dynamical systems. While the number-theoretic study of rational numbers and polynomial equations lies far from the chaos and fractals that arise in the study of dynamics, the two are tied together in this setting by p-adic dynamics. In addition, the PI will supervise undergraduate students in an REU summer research project to bolster their mathematical training. Any computational data produced in the REU will be published or posted on the web, for the benefit of the larger research community. Results from the project will also be disseminated via websites such as arXiv and via publication in mathematical journals.

The specific questions to be studied arise in two areas within arithmetic dynamics: first, the action of Galois groups on dynamical orbits, and second, moduli spaces of nonarchimedean dynamical systems. On the Galois side, certain p-adic dynamical features are essential to exhibiting enough Galois automorphisms to generate the complicated Galois groups in question. On the moduli space side, nonarchimedean dynamics has evolved into an established field of research, but relatively little is currently known about one-parameter families of nonarchimedean dynamical systems. The project will focus on dynamics on the Berkovich projective line, the appropriate space on which one-variable nonarchimedean systems act. The problems to be explored are new areas that are continuations of rich theories with long histories in dynamics, Galois theory, and nonarchimedean analysis. In particular, the first topic promises to provide new dynamical tools for addressing the study of absolute Galois groups, while the second promises new approaches to moduli problems in arithmetic dynamical systems.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
Arithmetic dynamics is a mathematical field lying at the interface between the study of dynamical systems (popularly known as chaos theory) and number theory. This project focused on two objects that are of fundamental importance at the cutting edge of research in arithmetic dynamics: on the analytic side, the Berkovich projective line as the appropriate setting for dynamical systems defined over nonarchimedean fields, and on the algebraic side, arboreal Galois groups. The PI attacked and solved a number of open questions surrounding these objects.
The Intellectual Merit results of the project on the Berkovich space side began with a stability theorem for nonarchimedean dynamical moduli spaces of arbitrary dimension; this was joint work of the PI and Junghun Lee. The PI is currently extending these results (by sharpening the stability condition) in in-progress joint work with Laura DeMarco. In each case, a certain natural condition on a rational function's dynamical system is shown to imply that all nearby systems in the dynamical moduli space have conjugate dynamics on their associated Julia sets, which lie in Berkovich space.
Non-archimedean dynamics similarly underlay the PI's joint work with Vefa Goksel on the arithmetic properties of Gleason and Misiurewicz polynomials, which pick out the parameter values in dynamical moduli spaces at which a given system is postcritically finite, or PCF, leading to special dynamical behaviors.
The Broader Impacts of the project include the PI's expository paper on nonarchimedean dynamics, in the Berkovich space setting, to provide an entry point for other mathematicians to approach the field.
The arboreal Galois side of the project concerns the towers of algebraic fields generated by iterated preimages of a chosen starting point under a given dynamical system. The PI proved new theorems in several collaborative works, all contributing to the Intellectual Merit of the project. First, with Dragos Ghioca, Jamie Juul, and Thomas Tucker, he proved new results on arboreal Galois groups associated with PCF polynomials. Second, with Anna Dietrich, he proved new explicit results on arboreal Galois groups associated with quadratic rational functions with colliding critical points, a less explicit version of which had first been investigated by Richard Pink. Third, with a group of five undergraduate students who were part of a 2022 summer REU the PI supervised, he proved another new set of results on arboreal Galois groups for cubic polynomials with colliding critical points.
The latter two results also contributed to the Broader Impacts of the project. Dietrich was an undergraduate at the time of the PI's initial work with her, as were all five of the REU participants. Thus, while proving new results of interest to the research community in arithmetic dynamics, the PI simultaneously provided teaching, training, and mentoring support to six students, four of whom are continuing on to graduate study in mathematics.
